data.title: Why did Bitcoin prices fall along with software stocks?
data.description:
Author: Anthony Pompliano, Founder and CEO of Professional Capital Management

Over the past few weeks, investors have been most focused on the rapid sell-off in software stocks. To better understand why, I asked Silvia (our AI-driven CFO) for an explanation. Here's what she said:

  • This sell-off, dubbed the "SaaS doomsday," has wiped out more than $1 trillion in market capitalization from software stocks since late January 2026. The primary driver is a sudden and intense investor concern: the emergence of artificial intelligence, particularly autonomous AI agents (such as Anthropic's Claude Cowork), is poised to disrupt the traditional SaaS business model. Investors worry that if AI tools can replace the entire software workflow—from coding to customer service to IT management—the seat-based subscription model that has underpinned SaaS valuations for a decade will be fundamentally threatened. According to USA Today and Reuters, the iShares Technology Software ETF (IGV) has fallen approximately 20% year-to-date, with major companies suffering heavy losses: Microsoft is down about 28% from its peak, Oracle is down about 55%, Salesforce is down about 30%, and Adobe is down about 27%. Adding to the woes, the sector is experiencing a massive rotation. Funds are flowing out of traditional SaaS companies and into AI infrastructure companies, value stocks, and industrial sectors. Despite largely stable fundamentals, the software sector's forward price-to-earnings ratio has compressed from approximately 39 times to 21 times, falling to a multi-year low. According to AInvest data, all software companies in the S&P 500 that reported earnings beat expectations last quarter, with 80% exceeding revenue expectations. Companies like ServiceNow and AppLovin reported record earnings, but their share prices still suffered heavy losses because Wall Street's focus has shifted from current profitability to ultimate value—essentially questioning whether these established companies can survive in a world of autonomous AI agents. JPMorgan Chase called the sell-off driven by "logical inconsistencies," believing the market is digesting a worst-case scenario that hasn't yet occurred. These are significant promises that short sellers rely on to support their investment logic. The sudden and significant reduction in the market capitalization of all software companies compared to just a few weeks ago is truly perplexing.

    Silvia then explained the crux of the debate: Is this an overreaction by investors, or a structural turning point in the market?

    ... "Short sellers argue that AI agents will commoditize software, squeeze profit margins, and erode the user base—some analysts at Bain and Forrester point out that CIOs are consolidating software budgets and reallocating spending to AI tools rather than expanding SaaS reach. Bulls counter that deeply embedded 'record systems' platforms (like Salesforce, ServiceNow, and Intuit) have a sticky customer base and recurring revenue that won't disappear overnight, making their current valuations potentially an attractive entry point. The truth may lie somewhere in between—AI will reshape the industry, but this indiscriminate sell-off has depressed the stock prices of many quality companies as if their businesses were already on the decline, a conclusion the data doesn't yet support." One question I've been pondering is the relationship between software stocks and Bitcoin. If software stocks are falling due to concerns about artificial intelligence, why is Bitcoin falling at the same time? Are investors genuinely worried that AI will impact Bitcoin's future? Silvia explains this clearly: "In early 2026, the correlation between Bitcoin and software stocks surged to astonishing levels. As of February, Bitcoin's 30-day rolling correlation with the iShares Extended Technology Software ETF (IGV) reached 0.73, a very high figure. Bitcoin's correlation with the Nasdaq 100 also jumped from -0.68 to +0.72 in just a few weeks. Meanwhile, its correlation with gold was only 0.12. In effect, Bitcoin traded more like a high-beta software stock than a safe-haven asset." The mechanism driving this correlation is institutional fund flows, not fundamental overlap. Since the launch of spot Bitcoin ETFs in early 2024, Bitcoin has increasingly been included in institutional portfolios alongside growth and tech stocks. When risk aversion events occur—such as the sell-off in AI-driven software stocks triggered by the launch of Anthropic's Claude Cowork—portfolio managers broadly reduce risk, selling both software stocks and Bitcoin. At the peak of the sell-off, Bitcoin ETFs experienced average daily outflows of $272 million, with cumulative outflows from cryptocurrency products reaching $1.7 billion. This is not a phenomenon unique to cryptocurrencies—it's a broader risk aversion mechanism where funds shift from growth assets to gold, government bonds, and cash. Bitcoin, as a risk-averse asset, is also held by these institutions and is therefore affected by this countercurrent. The key nuance—and what makes this particularly tricky—lies in the negative skewness of Bitcoin's correlation with its price. Bitcoin falls much more sharply than it rises with software stocks. When IGV rises, Bitcoin's reaction is relatively muted; conversely, when IGV falls, Bitcoin tends to amplify the decline. This asymmetry exacerbates the situation—Bitcoin bears the risk of a decline in its correlation with tech stocks but fails to fully participate in their rallies. Stifel even predicts Bitcoin could fall to $38,000, pointing out that its 0.78 correlation with the Nasdaq 100 suggests that Bitcoin is now more like a leveraged bet on tech stocks than a safe-haven asset for the dollar. Clearly, the current sell-off is highly correlated. The most likely scenario for this correlation to disappear is that institutional investors no longer view Bitcoin as a growth/risk asset. As long as Bitcoin remains in the same category as software stocks in institutional portfolios and is influenced by the same macroeconomic factors (Fed policy, liquidity, risk appetite), it will continue to trade like leveraged tech stocks. To change this, a large number of marginal buyers of Bitcoin need to shift from momentum-chasing hedge funds and ETF-driven retail investors to structural, price-insensitive holders… primarily those who adhere to long-term holdings regardless of quarterly macroeconomic changes. The most likely catalyst is widespread adoption by sovereign nations. The United States has established a strategic Bitcoin reserve using seized assets, while countries like Brazil, El Salvador, and Bhutan are exploring or actively accumulating Bitcoin as a sovereign reserve. For the first time since 1996, central bank gold reserves have surpassed foreign holdings of US Treasury bonds, potentially representing a structural "sovereign asset rotation" from which Bitcoin could benefit if it ultimately proves to be a reliable neutral reserve asset. If major central banks (especially sovereign wealth funds) begin actively purchasing Bitcoin, this will create a large, price-insensitive demand base, absorbing selling pressure during periods of heightened risk aversion and fundamentally reducing its correlation with stocks. Gold's trajectory is largely consistent with this, and Bitcoin aspires to follow a similar path. The decoupling of Bitcoin from software stocks will be a multi-year process. This requires a gradual shift in the Bitcoin holder base from speculative/institutional investors to sovereign/structural investors, reduced volatility, and at least one crisis where Bitcoin doesn't sell off along with all other assets. The sovereign reserve trend is currently the most promising catalyst, but as long as exchange-traded fund (ETF)-driven institutional flows dominate Bitcoin's marginal pricing, it will still behave like an extension of the high-beta growth/tech sector during periods of market stress. Therefore, one way to understand Bitcoin's current correlation is that this asset is a victim of its own success. What we want is mainstream acceptance, and we have achieved that, but this mainstream acceptance (especially on Wall Street) has had side effects. The new correlation with software stocks is the most obvious example. Bitcoin is definitely fine. I expect it to continue to perform well in the future. The challenge for you as investors is to avoid getting bored. Good luck.

data.title: The US's Hunt for Bitcoin: From the Silk Road to the World's Largest Government Holder

As of February 2026, the U.S. government held approximately 328,372 Bitcoins, representing approximately 1.64% of the global circulating supply (approximately 19.9 million Bitcoins). Based on current market prices, the value exceeds $20 billion. With this scale, the United States becomes the world's largest holder of Bitcoin, far exceeding any other government. Almost all of these Bitcoins came from law enforcement seizures, not from government appropriations or market purchases. While cracking down on the illicit uses of Bitcoin, the United States has quietly transformed these "criminal assets" into a national strategic reserve. Looking back at the US law enforcement and regulatory actions surrounding cryptocurrencies over the past decade, from cracking down on dark web markets to on-chain tracking and cross-border collaboration, it's clear that the US has never truly intended to "eliminate" Bitcoin. Instead, it has focused on controlling its flow and use, incorporating it into national strategic reserves, and forming a closed loop that integrates technology, law, and assets.

Timeline: Landmark Actions in the US Hunt for Bitcoin

2011-2013

2013-2014Year: The Hunting of Multiple Dark Web Markets and the Laying of a Regulatory Framework

After the Silk Road ended, the United States did not stop. On March 18, 2013, FinCEN (Financial Crimes Enforcement Network) issued guidance classifying Bitcoin exchanges and similar services as "money services businesses". The requirement for registration and implementation of KYC/AML (Know Your Customer) anti-money laundering mechanisms (MBL) by the US (Manufacturing Transaction Management System) marked the true beginning of the US Bitcoin regulatory framework, forcing exchanges to comply with regulations. In November 2014, the FBI, along with Europol and law enforcement agencies from 17 countries, launched Operation Onymous, simultaneously shutting down over 400 [unclear - possibly related to security measures]. The dark web market includes major drug and counterfeit money laundering sites such as Silk Road 2.0, Cloud 9, and Hydra. Arrests were made against more than 17 operators, including Blake Benthall, operator of Silk Road 2.0, and “Defcon”, a San Francisco software developer; approximately $1 million in Bitcoin and €180,000 in cash, gold, drugs, etc., were seized. The key weapon at this stage is the "civil forfeiture" system, which allows assets to be frozen with only a preponderance of evidence and without criminal conviction. The U.S. Marshals Service subsequently began regularly auctioning off confiscated Bitcoin. In 2014, investor Tim Draper participated in the auction, becoming one of the early public buyers. With a two-pronged approach of crackdown and compliance, Bitcoin was pulled from the underground into the regulatory order. 2017-2018: ICO Bubble Burst and Securities Regulation. After the ICO craze swept the globe, US regulators began a systematic cleanup. The SEC considers a large number of ICOs as “unregistered securities” and initiates enforcement actions against the project teams; the CFTC, on the other hand, has confirmed that Bitcoin is a “commodity”. The government has incorporated these regulations into its own oversight. Administrative fines, asset freezes, and litigation threats have been implemented. Centralized projects are forced to comply with regulations, reshaping the industry's financing model. While decentralized systems have gained room for development, compliance costs have increased significantly. 2020: The Aftermath of the Silk Road The 2012-2013 Silk Road hacking incident. This operation spanned seven years. Law enforcement used on-chain analytics tools such as Chainalysis and TRM Labs to track the flow of cold wallets through cluster analysis and transaction pattern matching, completing civil seizures without the need for private keys.

2021Year: Second Largest Encrypted ForfeitureJames ZhongCase

IRSThe Bureau of Criminal Investigation (IRS-CI) raided a Georgia home and found a hardware wallet in a floor safe and a popcorn bucket.

 As early as 2012, during the Silk Road era, Zhong used a fake merchant account to exploit a vulnerability in "Instant Withdrawal" to steal approximately 50,000 Bitcoins within a few days. When arrested in 2021, police seized 50,676 bitcoins, worth approximately $3.36 billion. Even though Bitcoin is designed to be decentralized, operational security errors can still lead to arrest. The IRS achieves asset seizure through physical searches, on-chain intelligence, and plea bargaining. Zhong ultimately pleaded guilty and was sentenced to just over one year in prison.

2022-2023Year:Bitfinex

2023-2025Year: Zhao Changpeng (CZ) and the Binance case

In November 2023, Binance admitted to failing to effectively implement anti-money laundering measures, allowing sanctioned users to trade, and paying a fine of $4.35 billion, including the confiscation of $2.7 billion in illicit gains; founder Changpeng Zhao

$50 million. During the investigation, US law enforcement not only relied on on-chain fund flow monitoring but also pieced together management's understanding of compliance risks by obtaining internal communication records. This included details such as the use of encrypted communication software to handle sensitive information and the deliberate downplaying of "US user" identification in internal discussions, forming evidence of the company's long-term evasion of KYC obligations. In April 2024, Zhao Changpeng was sentenced to four months in prison and served his sentence. In October 2025, President Trump announced a pardon for him. 2025: A Strategic Shift and the Largest Confiscation in History If the actions of the previous decade or so were a process of hunting down and purging, then 2025 saw a directional shift. On March 6, 2025, Trump signed an executive order establishing the Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and the U.S. Digital Asset Reserve. Previously, all Bitcoins seized by law enforcement would no longer be auctioned off, but instead become long-term national reserve assets and could not be sold. The policy logic has thus been rewritten, shifting from "post-crackdown auction for monetization" to "zero-cost strategic holding". On October 14th, the U.S. Department of Justice imposed sanctions on Chinese citizens of Cambodia's Prince Group. Chen Zhi, founder of [company name], was charged with criminal offenses including conspiracy to commit wire fraud and conspiracy to commit money laundering, and was ordered to forfeit approximately 127,271 Bitcoins, which at the time were worth approximately $15 billion, setting a record for the largest forfeiture of virtual assets in U.S. judicial history. The US claims the assets are related to cross-border telecom fraud and money laundering, and have entered a government escrow system. The China National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center released a technical tracing report, pointing out that a large-scale Bitcoin theft occurred at LuBian's mining pool in 2020, with the amount highly consistent with the scale of this seizure, and raising technical questions about the acquisition method. This incident is not only an unprecedented seizure of virtual assets, but also a landmark case of the intertwined struggle between law enforcement power, technical capabilities, and narrative power in the digital asset field. Concurrently, the Russian-operated Garantex exchange and its successor, Grinex, have been accused of providing money laundering channels for sanctioned countries' hacking and fraud, and have continued to face sanctions and infrastructure attacks. The interplay between on-chain tracking, pressure on the dollar clearing system, and control of physical servers systematically demonstrates cross-border law enforcement capabilities. After being placed on the sanctions list in early 2022, in March 2025, the U.S. Secret Service, in conjunction with German and Finnish law enforcement agencies, seized its domain name and froze approximately $26 million in assets; the Department of Justice indicted several executives, including Aleksej Besciokov, who was arrested in India; In August, the U.S. Treasury Department further expanded the scope of sanctions against OFAC, and the State Department offered a reward of up to $5 million for the capture of those responsible. With this, the U.S. has completed a closed loop in its handling of crypto assets, enabling it to both suppress, freeze, and confiscate them, as well as hold them long-term and incorporate them into national reserves. From technological suppression to asset integration, Bitcoin has been incorporated into the national strategic framework. From Hunting to Nationalization The United States' approach to Bitcoin has shifted from viewing it as a tool to combating crime to incorporating it as a national strategic asset. It's not just about law enforcement and regulation of cryptocurrencies; it's about achieving control over the entire Bitcoin supply chain and integrating national interests through a high degree of synergy between technology, law, and strategic reserves. Leveraging its globally leading on-chain tracing technology, national-level cyberattack capabilities, and transnational collaboration, the United States has constructed a three-pronged closed loop of "technological advantage—regulatory binding—institutional enforcement," making Bitcoin a crucial component of its financial resilience and international dominance.

1. Technical Aspect

The United States, relying on its globally leading on-chain tracing technology, national-level cyber attack capabilities, and transnational cooperation, has achieved precise control over the entire Bitcoin chain. On-chain traceability capabilities: The United States possesses the world's most advanced on-chain traceability technology, with leading US companies such as Chainalysis and Elliptic holding over 90% of the market share. The above market share allows for clustering and tracking of over 99% of Bitcoin transactions. Even using CoinJoin or mixers, on/off-ramp (fiat currency inflows and outflows) often exposes address associations. Combining Physics and Law: Without cracking private keys, hardware wallets, exchange accounts, or cloud storage files can be directly controlled through search warrants or court orders. In the Chen Zhi case, 25 cold wallet addresses were precisely located; in the Bitfinex case, direct control of assets was achieved by obtaining private keys through cloud storage. National-level cyberattack capabilities: The United States has launched targeted attacks against global exchanges and mining pools, including backdoor implantation, spear-phishing, supply chain infiltration, and exploitation of underlying encryption vulnerabilities. The LuBian mining pool case exploited the weakness of pseudo-random numbers, precisely transferring over 127,000 Bitcoins within 2 hours, demonstrating technological dominance. International Cooperation and Long-Arm Jurisdiction: Sharing intelligence with the EU, the UK, etc., and imposing sanctions on companies like OFAC, Tornado Cash, and Garantex, combined with dollar clearing hegemony, domain name seizures, and transnational arrests, to form a global hunting network and achieve full-chain control of digital assets. 2. Legal and Institutional Levels The United States, through legal systems and technological cooperation, has incorporated Bitcoin into its national control system, providing a solid guarantee for its strategic reserves. The GENIUS Act requires stablecoin issuers to use over 80% of their reserve assets to purchase U.S. Treasury bonds, creating sustained demand for U.S. Treasury bonds and binding the crypto ecosystem to the dollar system. The BITCOIN Act establishes the link between virtual assets and the U.S. financial system, clarifies civil forfeiture mechanisms, and provides legal support for the transfer of assets to state ownership. Civil confiscation: Assets can be seized without criminal conviction, resulting in extremely high efficiency. From 2022 to 2025, the United States confiscated over $30 billion worth of virtual assets globally through various cases, with the Chen Zhi case alone accounting for 50%. This synergy between law and technology forms a complete closed loop of "rule pre-setting — technology forensics — asset harvesting," providing institutional guarantees for strategic reserves. 3. Strategic Reserve Approach The US's handling of Bitcoin reflects a complete evolution from precise targeting to systematic harvesting, and finally to its inclusion in national strategic reserves. Through a high degree of synergy in technology, regulations, and international cooperation, the US has established full-chain control over global virtual assets. Its methods include: precise monitoring and control of transactions using on-chain tracking technology and state-level cyberattack capabilities; direct transfer of assets through court orders and civil forfeiture; and forming a global encirclement loop through cooperation with allies, OFAC sanctions, domain name seizures, and transnational law enforcement. Case studies demonstrate the high efficiency of this capability: in the Chen Zhi case, confiscated assets were directly placed under state control; in the Zhao Changpeng case, through rule-based export and technological tracking, the United States rapidly transformed cross-border assets into strategic reserves. This strategy allows the United States to incorporate seized assets into its national reserves without requiring market purchases, using Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation and volatility in the dollar system, essentially as "digital gold." As of February 2026, the United States held approximately 328,372 Bitcoins, representing 1.64% of the global circulating supply, with a value exceeding $20 billion, almost entirely from confiscation operations. On March 6, 2025, the United States signed an executive order entitled "Establishing a Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and a U.S. Digital Asset Reserve," officially designating Bitcoin as a strategic reserve asset and requiring the Treasury Department to cease auctioning and selling Bitcoin obtained through judicial seizures and to transfer it to a newly established strategic reserve account. Although the BITCOIN Act recommended purchasing 1 million tokens over five years, this has not yet been implemented; the executive order only authorizes a potential strategy of "budget neutrality and no additional taxpayer costs." Open market purchases have not been implemented, nor has any explicit commitment been made. Overall, the United States' strategy is highly systematic, neither completely eliminating nor completely abandoning Bitcoin, thus achieving precise control and strategic utilization. From a tool of crime in the "Silk Road" era to a core asset of national strategic reserves, the evolution of Bitcoin reflects a new landscape of national technological hegemony in the digital age, strengthening the United States' dominance in the global digital financial system and profoundly impacting technological sovereignty, economic interests, and political security.

▌What is the value of BTC?

BTC is often compared to "digital gold," but its core value is actually the "promise of immutable scarcity." First, BTC has monetary properties, but it is not a currency because it lacks a stable unit of account. It is a pure "monetary property," that is, a consensus game among humans regarding "what can serve as a store of value." Gold also has this core value, but gold's scarcity depends on the physical geological constraints, while BTC's scarcity depends on mathematics and game theory—it's an information-level scarcity.

But what makes BTC truly unique is not the coin itself, nor the "digital gold" narrative, but rather that blockchain is the first permissionless, unclosable value settlement layer in human history. This is a completely new category of infrastructure.

No sovereign entity can unilaterally prevent the final settlement of a BTC transaction. This property may be underestimated in peacetime, but it will be repriced during periods of geopolitical conflict and escalating capital controls. BTC is a systemic hedge. It is not a hedge against inflation, nor against the US dollar. It hedges against the structural degradation of institutional trust. In other words, BTC's value is not endogenous, but reflexive: the more people believe it has value, the more valuable it becomes, and vice versa. Therefore, BTC is a financialized expression of humanity's distrust of its own institutional capabilities. Its ceiling depends on the depth and breadth of this distrust, and its floor depends on the existence of a superior alternative.
